> **TL;DR**
>
> - **Purpose:** Manipulator robot for assembly and maintenance
> - **Mass:** ~370 kg
> - **Battery:** NaS 20 kWh + cable (optional)
> - **Power:** 5 kW
> - **Assembly time:** 48 hours per station

---

## Overview

Centaur-M is a universal Gen-2 manipulator robot for precision operations: equipment assembly, welding, maintenance. Four-wheel platform with two 6-axis manipulators and a tool set.

**Key feature:** The lightest Gen-2 robot (370 kg), maximum aluminum fraction (62%) to reduce mass.

---

## Centaur-M Material Balance

| Component | Material | Mass | Source |
|-----------|----------|------|--------|
| Frame + chassis | Steel Fe-6%Mn | 80 kg | [Frame Manufacturing](../elements/frames.qmd) |
| Body, radiators, manipulators | Aluminum | 230 kg | [Aluminum](../../materials/distillation.qmd) |
| NaS Battery | Na + S + β-Al₂O₃ | 40 kg | [Battery Production](../elements/batteries.qmd) |
| Actuators (12 pcs: 4 wheels + 2×6 manipulators) | Fe + Al + NaK | 15 kg | [Actuators](../elements/actuators.qmd) |
| Electronics | — | 5 kg | **Import from Earth** |
| **TOTAL** | — | **~370 kg** | **~99% local** |

**Material distribution:**
- Iron (Fe): 80 kg = **22%**
- Aluminum (Al): 230 kg = **62%**
- Sodium + Sulfur: 40 kg = **11%**
- Import: 5 kg = **1%**

## Assembly Process

### Assembly Line (10 stations, 48 hours per station)

| Station | Stage | Time | Robots |
|---------|-------|------|--------|
| 1 | Frame installation on jig | 1 hour | 1 Centaur-M |
| 2 | Chassis mounting (4 wheels) | 3 hours | 2 Centaurs-M |
| 3 | Al body and radiator installation | 4 hours | 2 Centaurs-M |
| 4 | NaS battery installation (20 kWh) | 2 hours | 1 Centaur-M |
| 5 | 2 manipulator mounting (6+6 axes) | 12 hours | 3 Centaurs-M |
| 6 | Power cable routing | 3 hours | 1 Centaur-M |
| 7 | Electronics installation (processor, sensors) | 4 hours | 2 Centaurs-M |
| 8 | NaK cooling loop filling | 1 hour | 1 Centaur-M |
| 9 | Manipulator calibration and testing | 14 hours | Automated |
| 10 | Initial battery charging | 4 hours | Charging station |
| **TOTAL** | | **48 hours** | |

---

## Stage 1: Frame Installation

**Centaur-M Frame:**
- Mass: ~310 kg (80 kg Fe + 230 kg Al)
- Design: Lightweight aluminum frame with steel load-bearing nodes
- Production: [WAAM 3D printing](../elements/frames.qmd)

**Process:**
1. Crane lifts frame from conveyor
2. Frame installed on assembly jig
3. Fixed on 4 supports
4. Geometry verification (laser scanner)

---

## Stage 2: Chassis Mounting

**4 wheels:**
- Diameter: Ø0.8 m
- Material: Aluminum (rim) + rubber (tread, imported)
- Drive: Electric motors 2 kW × 4 = 8 kW total

**Suspension:**
- Independent on each wheel
- Hydraulic shock absorbers (NaK)
- Suspension travel: ±150 mm

**Process:**
1. Install 4 hubs on frame (M16 bolts)
2. Mount drive electric motors
3. Install wheels
4. Alignment adjustment

---

## Stage 3: Body and Radiator Installation

**Aluminum body:**
- Mass: 100 kg (part of 230 kg Al)
- Design: Lightweight panels from 2 mm Al sheets
- Function: Electronics protection, radiators

**Radiators:**
- Area: ~5 m² (oriented toward shadow)
- Material: Aluminum
- Loop: NaK cooling for battery and processor

**Process:**
1. Install side panels (bolts + rivets)
2. Mount radiators on roof
3. Seal joints (TIG welding)

---

## Stage 4: NaS Battery Installation

**NaS Battery 20 kWh:**
- Mass: 40 kg
- Voltage: 200 V (100 cells × 2 V)
- Placement: Center of gravity (under platform)

**Optional cable:**
- For factory work, Centaur-M can operate from cable (10 kV)
- Cable reel on body (50 m)
- Automatic rewind on return

**Process:**
1. Lift battery with crane
2. Install in battery compartment
3. Connect power cables (M8 bolts)
4. Connect battery management system (BMS)

**Details:** [Battery Production](../elements/batteries.qmd)

---

## Stage 5: Manipulator Mounting

**2 manipulators with 6 axes:**

**Installation process:**
1. Mount manipulator base on frame (M20 bolts)
2. Install 6 manipulator links (each link — 200 mm)
3. Connect 6 electric actuators (1 per axis)
4. Route power and signal cables through manipulator
5. Install interchangeable attachment (TIG torch by default)

**Time:** 12 hours for 2 manipulators (most labor-intensive stage)

**Details:** [Actuators](../elements/actuators.qmd)

---

## Stage 6: Power Cable Routing

**Cables:**
- Main power cable: 25 mm² Al (200 V, 50 A)
- Manipulator control cables: 2×6 wires (axis signals)
- Tool power cable: 16 mm² Al (for welding, milling)

**Process:**
1. Route cables through cable channels
2. Connect to distribution panel
3. Insulation test (megohmmeter)

---

## Stage 7: Electronics Installation

**Centaur-M Electronics:**
- Processor: ARM Cortex-A72 (4 cores, 1.5 GHz)
- Sensors: 8 cameras, 2 lidars, GPS, IMU
- Communication: Wi-Fi, 2.4 GHz radio channel
- Mass: 5 kg

**Process:**
1. Install computer in protective enclosure
2. Connect cameras and lidars
3. Calibrate sensors
4. Install communication antennas

---

## Stage 8: NaK Cooling Loop Filling

**NaK Loop:**
- Volume: ~20 liters
- Temperature: +50-100°C (operating)
- Radiators: 5 m² Al panels

**Process:**
1. Evacuate loop (remove air)
2. Fill NaK through fill valve
3. Leak test (vacuum test)
4. Start NaK pump

---

## Stage 9: Manipulator Calibration and Testing

**Test Program:**

| Test | Description | Standard |
|------|-------------|----------|
| Manipulator calibration | Set zero positions for all 12 axes | Accuracy ±0.5 mm |
| Movement | Check all 4 wheels | Speed 5 km/h |
| Load pickup | Lift 50 kg at 1 m distance | Position accuracy ±1 mm |
| TIG welding | Weld test on Al plates | Defect-free weld |
| Battery | Full charge/discharge cycle | Capacity >18 kWh |
| Autonomy | Autopilot, obstacle avoidance | 100% success |

**Duration:** 14 hours (manipulator calibration takes significant time)

---

## Stage 10: Initial Charging

**Charging Station:**
- Voltage: 200 V
- Current: 25 A
- Full charge time: 4 hours (20 kWh / 5 kW)

**Process:**
1. Connect to charging station
2. Activate battery (first cycle at 350°C)
3. Full charge
4. Capacity verification (must be >18 kWh)

## Maintenance

| Operation | Frequency | Performed by |
|-----------|-----------|--------------|
| MoS₂ lubricant replacement in manipulators | 1 month | Another Centaur-M |
| Manipulator calibration | 1 month | Automated |
| NaS battery replacement | 5-7 years | Assembly line |
| Tool replacement (TIG torch, cutters) | As needed | Centaur-M self-service |

**Service life:**
- Frame: 10-15 years
- Manipulators: 5-10 years
- Battery: 5-7 years (4500 cycles)
- Electronics: 5-10 years
- **Robot overall:** 5-10 years

## Applications

**Main Centaur-M tasks:**

| Task | Description | % of time |
|------|-------------|-----------|
| Robot assembly | Component mounting on jig | 40% |
| Structure welding | TIG welding Al/Fe parts | 20% |
| CNC machining | Milling mounting surfaces | 15% |
| Equipment maintenance | Part replacement, adjustment | 15% |
| Testing | Product quality control | 10% |

**Productivity:**
- 1 Centaur-M can assemble 0.2 robots/day (5 Centaurs → 1 robot)
- 1 Centaur-M can service 20 equipment units/day
